A BALLADE, WROTTEN ON THE FEASTYNGE AND MERRIMENTES OF EASTER MAUNDAY O! list unto a wondrouse tale, O! listen grete and smalle, 'Tis of a famouse Citte Mayre, Sir John theye dyd hym call. A Grocere kind, Sir John hee was, Yn swete meates rare dealt hee, Yn almondes, raysins, sugarr, dates, Ande eke yn good bohee. Sir John hee had a roaringe trade, Yn Wood-street was his howse, So proud hee was, for othere folke He cared not a souse. Ande now the time drewe very nigh, When Cits are blithe and gay, Sir John sente to his Royall Prynce, Ande thus dyd kyndley saye. “Oh! may ytt please you, Royall Sir, “Att mye grete howse to dyne, “There you shall dayntee viands have, “Ande plente of good wine. “Oh! may ytt please you, Royall Sir, “From Courte to brynge with you “Of Dukes and Lordes a goodlee traine, “They'll fynde what Citts can doe.” The Prynce hee hearde the kynde requeste, Thenn to the Page dyd saye, Ah, wherefore, doe theye merre make, Quod hee—“'Tis Easterr Daye.” “Goe, gentle Page, and tell Sir John, “Thatt I with hym will dyne, “Goe say, onn Easter Maundaye, I “Wyll feaste and drynke hys wine.” “Goe, tell hym, manye goodlee Lords, “His curtesy shall know.” The Page thenn made a wondrouse legge, Ande toe Sir John dyd goe. Ande whenn untoe Sir Mayre hee came, These tydinges straighte tolde hee; Quoth John—“Thou arte myne Page belov'dd, “I'll give thee pieces three.” Ande fromm hys pouche Sir Mayre thenn tooke Of goulde a precyouse store, And yn the Pages palme hee putt Three pieces and noe more. Sir John hee smyl'd, Sir John was glad, Hee was as sugarr swete, Toe hym ytt seem'd as fyggs toe boys, A moste delycyouse trete. “Come buske yee nowe mye merre menn, “Come buske yee one ande all, “Toe Cornhill speede toe Masterr Birch, “Ande eke toe Leadenhall.” “Goe run toe Butcherrs, Poult'rers, Cookes, “Goe buye upp all you see, “Goe purchase goods of ev'ry oune, “Save only Grocerie. “For sweetes belonge toe mee, Sir John, “Lett hym thatt dares saye naye.” Fromm oute the presence hied eche oune, Ande tooke a diff'rente waye. Sir John thenn gave toe eche commaunde: There came toe hys abode, Of trees so greene ande statues too, Full manye a waggon loade. These statues theye hadd heades of stone, Yes, theye were brainlesse all, Too like, I feare mee, manye guestes Att thys moste wondrouse balle. Ande now Sir John hys ticketts sente, The Pages swifte dyd runn, But Mister Sherives, straunge to telle, Had eche of them butt one. Now straunge, indeede, thys mattere was, Forr ev'ry yere befoure, Good Mister Sherives us'd toe have Foure ticketts, sometymes moure. Ande soe these Sherives lookedd grim, And eache hys lypp dyd teare, Theire spouses gnaw'd theire fynger nayls, And eke theire daughterrs fayre. Ande whye? because their kyrtles alle With lace theye hadd bedyghte, Thatt theye myghte feste att Mansyon Howse, And see the comlee syghte. Ande soe 'twixte Sherrives and Sir John, Grete dudgeon was I trow, Soe trulee piteous was the case, Toe Balle theye woud nott goe. Ande nowe enrag'd, we'll leave these wights, Ande speake of Mister Mayre, We'll telle yee how att Mansyon Howse The feaste hee dyd prepare. The Cooks dyd worke till brinee sweate Ran tricklynge downe a floode, Theyre locks look shyne as yf oyl'd, Theyre cheekes were redd as bloode. No ynmate of thys spacyouse howse Butt bytterlee dyd sweare, All, save Sir Johnny ande hys dame, Ande eke theyre daughtere fayre. For naughte had theye toe doe butt dress, And thynke how fyne 'twould bee, The Royall Prynce and Nobles alle, At Mansyon Howse toe see. Ande nowe the hours rowl'd onn apace, And belles full loude dyd rynge, All seem'd as blythe as yf yt were The crownynge of a Kynge. Ande nowe the coaches drove alonge, Eache hackney had a jobb; Such tribes dyd flocke the Prynce toe see, Theye made a wond'rouse mobb. Ande soe theye pour'd yn thicke and faste, With eche hys bonnet trim, Ande some were tall ande some were shorte, Some fatt, some verye thin. For fatte toe Yealdermenn belonges, As ev'rye oune dothe knowe, Because theye guttle Turtle Soupe, And feaste on Venson soe. Thenn with hys Courtiers came the Prynce, Surrounded bye a thronge, Thatt were soe glad hys face toe see, Theye drew hys coache alonge. With Englishmenn 'tis ever soe, Lyke apes befoure a glasse, New objects please, theye gape and grynne, And acte themmselves the ass. For ass-lyke sure ytt was toe see The nobleste worke of God, Enacte the beaste, ande dragg a coache, Beneathe the driverrs rodd. Ande thenn Sir John the Prynce receivedd, Ande eke hys Nobles too, Theye scrap'd ande eache dyd complemente, What else shoud Courtyers doe. Thenn downe theye satt toe eate ande drynke, Theyre mouthes wente oune ande alle, Theye ate ande dranke theyre bellies fulle, Ande thenn begann the Balle. The Prynce a Damsell handed forthe, Noe Damsell was more fayre, Shee was the peerless Daughter of Sir John the grete Lord Mayre. “Sir,” quod the Prynce, toe hym thatt dyd Of dauncinge here take leade, “Goe bydd themm playe a minuett, “Goe bydd themm playe withe speede.” Now foolish look'd the Gentlemann Thatt dyd the whyte wande houlde, So timid was hee fore the Prynce, Though yn the Citte bolde. Yet though soe timid, styll hee thoughte He'd doe a handsome thynge, Ande therefore bad the fiddlers alle Strike upp God save the Kynge. Att thys the Prynce hadd verye nyghe Hys sydes wyth laughtere splytte, As well hee myghte, the complemente Being worthye such a Citt. Att length begann the minuetts, The Prynce turned oute hys toes, Ande soe dyd Miss, her cheekes nowe payle, Thenn redd as anye rose. Thenn alle att ounce began to move, I wyll nott calle ytt dance, For manye hadd noe eares att alle, Ande some dyd naughte butt prance. As well theyre eares for tyme were fytt, As Guildhall's huge Magog, Ande as for footynge just as welle Had danc'd a grunting hog. The Prynce ere midnighte bad farewelle, Ande toe the Pallayce sped, The Nobles too left Mansyonne Howse, Ande hied them home toe bedd. Then decencye was soone forgott, With youths 'tis oft' the case, They spilt Metheglyn and theyre wyne, Spytt yn eache otheres fayce. Ande soe tylle morne wythe sugar'd sack, Dydd eache hys noddle drenche, Ande thenn tow'rds Cheape theye reel'd lyke Lords, Eache readye forr his wench. Ande thus wee leave themm, forr I'm sure Noe pastyme cann compare Toe thatt whych lads whenn warm'd with sack, Taste wythe the wyllynge fayre. Thenn God protecte ande bless oure Prynce, Ande save hys Nobles too, Ande maye Sir John and Sherrives alle Theyre quarrel never reue; But soone forgett the reuefull chaunce Whych caus'd thys myghtye route, And as 'twas follye ledd them yn, Maye Turtle gett them oute. Forr att the nexte grete feaste I'm sure, Alle malyce wyll bee o'er, They'll shake eache otheres greasy paws, Nor thynke of Ticketts moure. FINIS.
